BE

Suntrust, just for a change, since we don't quote them much.

BE

The latest producer meeting in Doha continues to highlight the dissension amongst large oil producers, in particular Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Russia, as the meeting ended with no agreement to freeze oil production. As a result, oil futures are down materially and possibly could retrace a significant amount of its gains experienced over the past couple of months, sending oil service (OFS) and exploration & production (E&P) stocks down along with it. Time to focus on defense and quality once again for at least the near term. Doha Meeting Ends With No Agreement - Another oil producer meeting ends with disappointment, as 16 countries in attendance could not come to an agreement that would freeze each country's production through October of this year at January levels. It seems that Saudi Arabia was unwilling to agree to a freeze unless all major producers, including Iran, also agreed to freeze production. Iran was unwilling to agree
to such measures as they continue with plans to ramp production to pre-sanction levels. In fact, Iran's oil minister did not attend Sunday's Doha meeting and said he would not sign any deal that would amount to self-imposed sanctions.
Did A Freeze Really Mean Anything? Without Iran, an agreement amongst the 16 countries in attendance really didn't mean all that much, especially since the two major producers, Saudi Arabia and Russia, had not increased their country's production since January.
Doha Failure Highlights the Dissension Amongst OPEC Members - Investor sentiment was building that an oil-freeze agreement at Doha could help restore some OPEC credibility. However, the latest failure to reach an agreement cripples any hope that some form of coordination amongst major oil producers can
accelerate the rebalancing of global oil markets. Simply, Saudi won't agree to freeze production unless all major oil producers agree to freeze as well. And Iran won't agree to freeze until it's production reaches presanction levels. Therefore, we don't expect a production freeze agreement to come out of the next OPEC meeting on June 2nd.

BE

And Macquarie.

11:10 am
BE

 We see potential risk to crude oil balances in 2H16 from a return of up to
500 K BPD from the Neutral Zone, which despite recent constructive
commentary from Kuwait, has remained in doubt given the “freeze”
discussions.
 Iran’s loadings are significantly ahead of schedule and we estimate Iran is
now loading 550 K BPD greater than the beginning of this year.
 Per recent comments from the Deputy Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, KSA
could add up to 1 MM BPD to global crude supply immediately if the country
so desired. Though we assign low probability to this outcome, the
commentary speaks to ample latent capacity in KSA.
 As of Friday’s CFTC update, net futures equivalent length in WTI and Brent
stood at 560 K contracts, an increase of 330 K contracts from January.
 This weekend’s outcome, a culmination of deep-seated tensions between
Saudi and Iran, in addition to the latter’s unexpected success in ramping
exports post-sanctions, and recent escalation, in our view, highlights this risk.
 We viewed this “freeze” deal as largely costless to all parties involved, including
Saudi Arabia. As such, its failure is particularly notable.

BE

 Commentary from the CP of KSA that all OPEC producers join the freeze
appears to be more than rhetoric. The Doha meeting does not change our
constructive long-term view on oil but the “lower-for-longer” risk comes from
production growth from KSA and its GCC peers in response to Iran.
o While Saudi’s insistence on maintaining growth optionality as long as
other OPEC producers (chiefly Iran) do the same may be driven by
positioning for future OPEC discussions, pure rivalry vs. Iran can’t be
dismissed.

BE

We continue to expect WTI to trade back down towards the low-mid $30 range in
the near-term. Further, although we see a path back to S/D balance by YE16,
price insensitive production growth from Saudi Arabia and Iran pose a meaningful
risk to this view that we expect to drive near-term sentiment. We expected very
little from this meeting, but the utter dysfunction within OPEC that this failure
confirmed is a clear negative, in our view.

11:12 am
BE

And RBC.

BE

With his decision to double down on the demand for full Iranian participation in a freeze
agreement, Saudi Arabia’s de-facto ruler Mohammad bin Salman (MBS) proved to be the
ultimate disruptor at Sunday’s much anticipated meeting of sovereign producers in Doha. Saudi Arabia stood firm despite the determined efforts of its key GCC allies such as Qatar and Kuwait, which normally stand shoulder to shoulder with the Kingdom on oil policy, to forge an agreement to freeze output at January levels irrespective of Iranian involvement. Iran’s decision not to even attend the meeting and its repeated rejection of the freeze likely hardened Saudi’s resolve to stick to its guns. The assembled oil minsters tried their best to put a positive spin on the outcome, with the Qatari minister insisting that the group needed more time to finalize a deal and that improving fundamentals removed some of the immediate urgency. Nigeria’s oil minister also indicated that the group would reassemble again around the June OPEC meeting to try to craft a compromise. However, unless Saudi Arabia or Iran has a change of heart, we fail to see how the outcome will be any different, and it may ultimately be mounting supply disruptions in stressed states, rather than collective cartel action, that causes an accelerated market rebalancing.

BE

We previously suggested that the market’s reaction to the Doha meeting would hinge not only on a potential agreement but also on whether or not the group is able to control the rhetoric coming out of the meeting. While the market arguably had few expectations for an incrementally bullish outcome, the inability of the group to convey a position of strength points to prices kicking off the Monday session on a weaker footing. The post-Doha initial knee-jerk reaction lower is expected, but we expect prices to find support in the mid-$30/bbl range given an otherwise improving fundamental backdrop. The inability to strike a deal is not for lack of trying, so despite calls for further consultation and potential follow-up meetings, this botched attempt at a deal may sterilize the influence on prices leading into future meetings.

11:14 am
PM

A Week in China: THE US$22trn QUESTION

The 2009-esque improvement in China’s economy (shown by the 6.7% Q1 GDP growth and better than expected industrial data) is largely due to a) an exceptional rise in credit and b) stabilisation in the property market. This means that as well as continued growth in consumption and services, as shown by the rise in our New China Index, the old economy is seeing the first signs of light after two years of deepening gloom and this should continue into Q2.

So, the question being asked is: when does this stop? How can China keep pumping money into its economy at ever-lower rates of return? We reckon that it can continue for at least another year, but the factor which ends this is when China can no longer keep growing its US$22trn money supply at the same pace in the face of credit defaults, RMB depreciation and capital outflows. June is a potential flashpoint, even if until then the indicators are likely to improve.

PM

PROPERTY: The most important area for stabilisation in China after two years of 15% falls in floor space started was property developers starting up the diggers again. New starts were up 27% in March and 19% in Q1, helped by a 6.5% increase in loans, 40% in mortgages in Q1 and record bond issuance.
With Tier 2 cities effectively stabilising (and the Tier 1 in bubble territory) this supports construction into H2, benefitting the old economy sectors of Mining, Industrials and Construction in both the Chinese and International markets.

INFRASTRUCTURE: The government unveiled a 6trn yuan infrastructure and R&D program to support growth into H2, with this already being seen in the 19.6% rise in infrastructure spending in Q1 (vs. 10.7% ytd overall), supported by a 16.9% rise in state spending and new loans.
With most of this currently being ploughed into power and water investment (railways is lagging behind at -6.7% yoy), then this explains the copper restocking and stronger domestic cement prices in Q1 and April.

CONSUMPTION: The consumption side is still ticking along nicely, with autos up 12.3% yoy, mobile phones rising 16.5% and pharma up 19.8%, even if the lure of property investment has knocked jewellery sales (-9.3% yoy).

PM

So, as we wrote last week, all seems to be well with China following the monetary easing last year and the property market stabilisation.

The difficulty, as has been widely flagged, is that this comes with a hefty price tag – a 90% increase in total social financing to 2.3trn yuan and M2 of 13.4%. Our Shanghai economics team has repeatedly highlighted that China’s ever-decreasing economic efficiency means that ever more debt has to be piled into the economy just to stand still.

Given that China’s M2 already stands at US$22trn vs. the US at US$12trn, this is difficult, bordering on impossible, to maintain in the face of capital outflows, RMB depreciation and credit defaults. A combination of a seasonal end-Q2 interbank squeeze in China, a large credit default and a US interest rate increase would bring all this to a head in June 2016 (among all the other things to worry about that month), unless there is some heavy central bank intervention.

Brazil so fluffed

PM

The vote by the Brazilian lower house to send the impeachment case against President Rousseff to the Senate offers the prospect of a new more market-friendly government, most likely led by vice-president Temer. However, the new government will face daunting challenges, not least with a high and rising public debt burden (the IMF projects gross debt to rise to over 90% of GDP by 2021). The new government needs to implement very tough reforms to get the Brazilian economy back on track, which could be politically very challenging. With the prospect of a change in government there may well be downside risk to our forecast of USDBRL at 4.10 in 3M, but we will monitor the political transition over the coming week before considering a change to our forecast.

11:21 am
PM

And here's some Eurasia

PM

The Chamber of Deputies has approved the motion for impeachment
by a wide margin, which the Senate is likely to accept between May
10-12.
● But potential waning public support for impeachment and the risk Lava
Jato hits the PMDB means there is a 20% probability it won't pass.
● Vice president Michel Temer will appoint a very market-friendly
economic team and embark on a pro-business reform agenda should
he assume the presidency, but no announcements will be made before
the Senate’s decision.

PM

The Presidential Palace took a last gasp effort to revert the tide in favor of
Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment late Friday night and early Saturday morning,
but to no avail. As expected, the Lower House of Congress approved the
impeachment motion by a wide margin, with 367 votes in favor with 137
votes against (our estimates ranged between 370-380 votes in favor of
impeachment). The minimum necessary to approve a motion was 342 votes,
equivalent to 2/3 of all federal deputies in the lower house of Congress. The
motion now goes to the Senate, which then has to approve the petition by a
simple majority vote. Only then does the President Rousseff temporarily step
down while the Senate conducts an impeachment trial. The vote in the plenary
of the Senate should occur by May 10-12. In other words, Vice President
Michel Temer will most likely be acting President by mid-May.

11:22 am
PM

Let’s not take the Senate for granted
Most pundits, including Eurasia Group over the past few weeks, have been
of the view that if the Lower House of Congress approves a motion for
impeachment it would be all but guaranteed that the Senate follows suit and
upholds the motion. After all, with only 50% support needed to accept the
Lower House’s decision (41 of 81 senators), the bar to approve the lower
house’s motion is much lower. According to the latest Estado de S. Paulo
scoreboard, there are 44 pro-impeachment votes in the senate, 21 against,
with 16 undecided. A few factors, however, make us think the Senate should
not entirely be taken for granted. We give a 20% probability to a scenario
where the Senate doesn’t accept the lower house’s decision.

PM

It's ... how do I put this politely? ..... an extremely crowded long for reasons other than how Talazoparib-Chemo efficacy is balanced by myelosuppression.

BE

For what it's worth, AstraZeneca/MDVN seems to make a bit of sense on paper.

11:26 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Strategically Medivation would probably fit better with AZN than with Sanofi as AZN has a legacy prostate franchise (Casodex) where Medivation’s Xtandi would fit and has a breast cancer franchise (Ibrance, Zoladex, Faslodex) where Medivation’s PARP Talazoparib would fit. However there clearly would be overlap between AZN’s Lynparza (PARP inhibitor approved in ovarian cancer) and the former. AZN could attempt to bridge the gap between urologists and oncologists in prostate cancer better to create sales synergies. Whether Lynparza and Talazoparib could exist in parallel remains to be seen (Medivation pIII in breast cancer Q4 2016, AZN Lynparza pIII in BC also H2).

Transition period and I/O dependency. AZN is currently facing a transition period with statin Crestor going off-patent this year and diabetes as well as respiratory facing uphill battles. Bolstering the oncology franchise hence may be of interest to the company particularly as the current pipeline is heavily dependent on immuno-oncology where there is ongoing risk that AZN will not reach its ambitions. So bolt-on acquisitions that strengthen oncology and outside I/O may of high interest. The market seems aware of AZN’s position in I/O and a slight shift in focus should not be a big surprise.

Affordability. AZN is currently c1x EBITDA levered (ex pensions) which means Medivation’s current market cap of $9bn is not a daunting prospect. As per our last note on Sanofi, our US colleagues estimate EBIT for Medivation in 2016 of $372m and $690m in 2017. Given these EBIT estimates and assuming a finance rate in the low single digits, it would be hard to create a dilutive scenario.

PM

ongoing risk that AZN will not reach its ambitions.

BE

Reports in the media have
emerged that AstraZeneca is preparing to make a bid for MDVN. The
report additionally noted Celgene, Gilead and Roche as potential suitors.
This comes on the back of last week's news that Medivation had rejected
an offer from Sanofi. We have conducted a takeout analysis, where our M&A DCF values MDVN at up to $65/share to Sanofi, $60/share to Roche, and $75/share to AstraZeneca, where deeper synergies could be realized. (2) AGIO: AGIO and Celgene announced a
deferment of their selection process for allocating rights to late stage preclinical
cancer metabolism discovery programs. The agreement, originally
slated to expire April 14, has now been deferred to June while the two
companies explore alternative approaches to determine respective rights to
emerging cancer metabolism drug candidates (vs coin flip approach
previously included in agreement). (3) PBYI: Full results of neratinib's
NEfERT-T trial in 1L recurrent/metastatic HER2+ breast cancer were
published in JAMA Oncology this week. While neratinib-paclitaxel results
were in line with trastuzumab-paclitaxel on mPFS (primary endpoint),
neratinib did demonstrate a statistically significant 52% risk reduction
(HR=0.48, p=0.002) in the incidence of CNS disease recurrences.
However, note that the trial's protocol did not include screening for CNS
metastases, but rather identified upon symptom presentation. Moreover,
twice as many patients exhibiting CNS disease at baseline were in the
control arm. Given these factors, we agree with the study authors that while
the efficacy signal is promising, an appropriately designed, prospectively
stratified ph3 trial is needed to meaningfully elucidate neratinib's potential in
metastatic breast cancer patients with (or at risk for) CNS disease
progression / recurrence. Our model projects a 2018 launch and peak year
sales of $160M for this indication.

Whilst so, with the HOME deal to come, subject to the dizzying thought-processes of the UK Competition & Markets Authority, and a boost from potential corporate interest, Shore Capital reiterates our HOLD stance on Sainsbury's shares whilst noting that the other listed asset rich superstore groups, particularly freehold dominant Morrisons+ (MRW, House Stock, 195p) may gain a warm glow too in the aftermath of this story.

PM

For a total Consideration of £1.8 million, the Company will receive Angus' 7.8% beneficial interest in the Licences via the purchase of Angus' remaining 12% shareholding in Horse Hill Developments Limited ("HHDL"). The Consideration, with an effective date of 15 April 2016, is comprised of £1 million in cash and £0.8 million in the form of 43,886,116 UKOG ordinary shares. Furthermore, £200,000 of the cash element will be paid directly by Angus to the Licence Operator, HHDL, to reconcile cash calls for the now completed HH-1 flow test operations. The transaction requires no further regulatory approvals.

● Our view in a nutshell: We retain a cautious view about the tour operators
industry and still believe that it will need to continue to extract efficiencies to stay
competitive with the associated one-off restructuring costs. However, following
the escalation in geo-political risks recently, we feel that the underperformance is
overdone as we still expect the European consumer to go on holiday. We lift TUI to

BE

● Tour operators still face significant challenges: While both TUI and Thomas Cook
have materially repositioned their tour operating businesses, we still believe that
this is an industry that will face ongoing struggles when competing with the
disruptive online travel agencies and the low-cost airlines. We remain concerned
about the pace with which they will need to continue to fine-tune the cost
structure to keep pace, while we also fear that the tour operators will lose market
share (albeit modestly) and therefore trail the industry in terms of top-line growth.
● Exceptional cash costs have left industry cash flow modest: While both Thomas
Cook and TUI draw our attention to the underlying EBIT of the businesses, the
cash costs of extracting efficiencies to stay competitive have had a material impact
on the cash available to shareholders. In the case of Thomas Cook, without the
benefit of improved working capital management, cash flow would have been
negative. Cash generation is improving, but given the cyclicality of the industry
and the prospect of ongoing efficiencies, we remain concerned about the yield
being generated from the tour operator business.
● Geo-political risks have undermined share performance…: The heightening of
geo-political risks, particularly related to Turkey, has been a major issue for the
shares in TUI and Thomas Cook, which have both materially underperformed the
sector and the market ytd and over the past 12 months. While clearly these tragic
events will be a drag on the operational performance, we think this is now
adequately reflected in valuation. Clearly there is the risk of another incident,
which could yet weigh on the outcome for the year, but for now this appears to be
as well managed as possible by the industry.
● …but we will still go on holiday: The key reason that we believe that the risks are
adequately reflected is our belief that Europeans will still go on holiday. In this
regard we do agree with the operators that the booking curve may be out of shape
and delayed, but ultimately we expect the current strength of consumer confidence
to lead to bookings rising significantly over the coming months. The interim
results will be key in allaying some of these fears if there has been a recovery in
bookings.
● We prefer TUI: In our view, TUI continues to deliver a superior performance
within its tour operation business. This is reflected in a stronger top-line evolution
and also it has had a superior cash generation for shareholders. Furthermore, our
analysis suggests that the TUI tour operation business is trading at a material
discount to Thomas Cook if we put its Hotels and Cruises businesses on
appropriate multiples. Finally, there appears to be strong interest in the Hotelbeds
business, which we believe could lead to a sale price that is well received by the
market.

BE

■ Money 20/20 industry conference supports positive view: We
attended the Money 20/20 conference and hosted meetings with a
selection of public and private companies. The conference highlighted
four main themes: 1) growth prospects are sound and innovation and
complexity are accelerating; 2) we see no meaningful risks to the role of
Visa and Mastercard; 3) we see no short term risks of commoditisation;
and 4) we believe improving acceptance is the key challenge

BE

■ Worldpay (Upgrade to Outperform, TP 300p): In its maiden full year
results, Worldpay struggled to match high expectations. However, we
believe industry growth prospects remain robust and market leaders like
Worldpay are best positioned to take advantage of this growth and take
market share. The US was the area of disappointment, but we believe
newsflow will improve as we progress though FY16 and this will drive a
re-rating. As a result, we upgrade to Outperform (from Neutral) and
reiterate our 300p target price.

BE

Wirecard (Underperform, lower TP to €31 from €42): We think recent
FY15 results raise as many questions as they answer. Specifically cash
conversion was stronger than prior period, but reclassifications make the
working capital components hard to understand. Meanwhile, we think the
results reignite issues around the definition of net cash; some investors
believe that non-current debts should be included, reducing the net cash
to €118m vs the company definition at €536m. Until Wirecard can
demonstrate stronger cash flows without reclassifications, we reiterate
our Underperform stance.
